theoryText: Tom's philosophy about ships being neither good nor evil foreshadows the reveal about the Ancient Weapons and Pluton. Just as Tom taught that the ships themselves are neutral and it's the users who determine morality, this same principle applies to the Ancient Weapons - they are tools that can be used for good or evil depending on who wields them.
author: One Piece community discussion

theoryText: The symbolic parallel between Franky being run over by Tom's creation (the Sea Train) and later Franky building the Thousand Sunny for Luffy represents a cycle of creation and legacy. Just as Tom's creation inadvertently harmed Franky, Franky's own Battle Franky ships were used to harm Tom. This teaches Franky that he must build the Sunny with the understanding that it could be destroyed or misused, but he must still take pride in it.
author: One Piece analysis community

theoryText: Tom's unwavering pride in building the Oro Jackson for Gol D. Roger, even though it led to his execution, mirrors the Will of D. philosophy. Tom may not have the D. in his name, but his refusal to show regret and his commitment to his dreams despite the consequences align him spiritually with the D. clan's ideals of pursuing freedom and dreams without hesitation.
author: One Piece thematic analysis

theoryText: Spandam's obsession with obtaining Pluton to 'rule the world' parallels other World Government antagonists' desire for power through Ancient Weapons. This episode establishes a pattern that will be seen repeatedly - corrupt officials within the World Government seeking to use the very things they're meant to protect the world from, suggesting systemic corruption at the highest levels.
